body: Can you explain more about the exact logic flow in your test program? Maybe even produce an example that reproduces? So that we can test better and work on this.
Alternatively, you could [try to bisect](https://github.com/curl/curl/wiki/how-to-git-bisect) the exact change that caused this, as that would also be helpful.

rename.from: Regression: Unable to reuse curl handle after reset in libcurl 8.14.0
rename.to: FTP regression: Unable to reuse curl handle after reset in libcurl 8.14.0

body:
Okay, here is a slightly adjusted program with curl output. Note that this appears to only fail when connecting to MS FTP server. It works fine on e.g. vsftpd.

```C#
using System.Diagnostics;
using System.Text;
using Utiliread.Curl;
using Utiliread.Curl.Internal;
using static Interop.LibCurl;

Console.WriteLine("Curl version: " + Curl.GetVersion());

const string URL = "ftp://ftpserver.com:21/";
const string FTP_USERNAME = "ftpuser";
const string FTP_PASSWORD = "ftppassword";
const string PROXY_USERNAME = "proxyuser";
const string PROXY_PASSWORD = "proxypassword";
const string PROXY_HOST = "proxy.com";
const int PROXY_PORT = 1080;

static CurlWriteResult Receive(ReadOnlySpan<byte> data)
{
    return data.Length;
}

static void Configure(CurlEasy easy)
{
    easy.SetOpt(CURLoption.URL, URL, Encoding.Latin1);

    easy.SetOpt(CURLoption.USE_SSL, CurlUseSsl.All);
    easy.SetOpt(CURLoption.SSL_VERIFYPEER, 1);
    easy.SetOpt(CURLoption.SSLVERSION, CurlSslVersion.CURL_SSLVERSION_MAX_TLSv1_2);
    easy.SetOpt(CURLoption.SSL_OPTIONS, (int)CURLSSLoption.CURLSSLOPT_NATIVE_CA);

    easy.SetOpt(CURLoption.USERNAME, FTP_USERNAME, Encoding.UTF8);
    easy.SetOpt(CURLoption.PASSWORD, FTP_PASSWORD, Encoding.UTF8);

    easy.SetOpt(CURLoption.PROXYTYPE, CurlProxyType.Socks5);
    easy.SetOpt(CURLoption.PROXY, PROXY_HOST, Encoding.UTF8);
    easy.SetOpt(CURLoption.PROXYPORT, PROXY_PORT);
    easy.SetOpt(CURLoption.PROXYUSERPWD, $"{PROXY_USERNAME}:{PROXY_PASSWORD}", Encoding.UTF8);
}

curl_global_trace("all");

// WORKS WITH TWO EASY HANDLES

Debug.WriteLine("***** Running MLSD on first handle *****");

using (var easy = new CurlEasy())
{
    Configure(easy);
    easy.SetOpt(CURLoption.CUSTOMREQUEST, "MLSD", Encoding.ASCII);
    easy.WriteFunction = Receive;
    easy.SetOpt(CURLoption.NOPROGRESS, 0);

    try
    {
        easy.Perform();
    }
    catch (CurlException e) when (e.CURLcode == CURLcode.FTP_COULDNT_RETR_FILE)
    {
        // Expected
    }
}

Debug.WriteLine("***** Running LIST on second handle *****");

using (var easy = new CurlEasy())
{
    Configure(easy);
    easy.SetOpt(CURLoption.CUSTOMREQUEST, "LIST", Encoding.ASCII);
    easy.WriteFunction = Receive;
    easy.SetOpt(CURLoption.NOPROGRESS, 0);

    easy.Perform(); // Does not throw, i.e. SUCCESS
}

// DOES NOT WORK WITH ONE REUSED EASY HANDLE

Debug.WriteLine("***** Running MLSD on handle *****");

using (var easy = new CurlEasy())
{
    Configure(easy);
    easy.SetOpt(CURLoption.CUSTOMREQUEST, "MLSD", Encoding.ASCII);
    easy.WriteFunction = Receive;
    easy.SetOpt(CURLoption.NOPROGRESS, 0);

    try
    {
        easy.Perform();
    }
    catch (CurlException e) when (e.CURLcode == CURLcode.FTP_COULDNT_RETR_FILE)
    {
        // Expected
    }

    Debug.WriteLine("***** Running LIST on reused handle *****");

    // Reset and reuse
    easy.Reset();
    Configure(easy);
    easy.SetOpt(CURLoption.CUSTOMREQUEST, "LIST", Encoding.ASCII);
    easy.WriteFunction = Receive;
    easy.SetOpt(CURLoption.NOPROGRESS, 0);

    try
    {
        easy.Perform();
    }
    catch (CurlException ex) when (ex.CURLcode == CURLcode.FTP_WEIRD_PASV_REPLY)
    {
        Console.WriteLine("!!! TEST FAILED !!!");
        Debug.WriteLine("***** Got unexpected FTP_WEIRD_PASV_REPLY *****");
        throw;
    }
}
```

It looks like you don't enable the tracing again after the reset, do you?

~~~
 ***** Running LIST on reused handle *****
[1 12.20.28.658] Resetting curl handle 2186145867840
CURLINFO_TEXT: 12.20.28.661 [0-0] [READ] client_reset, clear readers

~~~

> Note that this appears to only fail when connecting to MS FTP server. It works fine on e.g. vsftpd.

A complication of course, as I am not aware of any publicly accessible MS FTP servers so we cannot reproduce this ourselves.

Okay, I now found out what was causing the trace output to not be included. That is fixed now, and the complete trace is included below.

One important observation that I found is that if I have a slow debug handler function, then the issue resolves itself.
This is the reason why I had to rewrite the way I collect the trace output (see modified code below). If I simply write directly to the debug output, then the code works. So I had to instead write to memory and then print out the trace after the test has failed.

<details>
<summary>Modified reproducing code where trace is now included after the reset</summary>

```C#
using System.Text;
using Utiliread.Curl;
using Utiliread.Curl.Internal;
using static Interop.LibCurl;

Console.WriteLine("Curl version: " + Curl.GetVersion());

const string URL = "ftp://ftpserver.com:21/";
const string FTP_USERNAME = "ftpuser";
const string FTP_PASSWORD = "ftppassword";
const string PROXY_USERNAME = "proxyuser";
const string PROXY_PASSWORD = "proxypassword";
const string PROXY_HOST = "proxy.com";
const int PROXY_PORT = 1080;

static CurlWriteResult Receive(ReadOnlySpan<byte> data)
{
    return data.Length;
}

static void Configure(CurlEasy easy)
{
    easy.SetOpt(CURLoption.DEBUGFUNCTION, (curl_debug_callback)DebugConsole.DebugFunction);
    easy.SetOpt(CURLoption.VERBOSE, 1);

    easy.SetOpt(CURLoption.URL, URL, Encoding.Latin1);

    easy.SetOpt(CURLoption.USE_SSL, CurlUseSsl.All);
    easy.SetOpt(CURLoption.SSL_VERIFYPEER, 1);
    easy.SetOpt(CURLoption.SSLVERSION, CurlSslVersion.CURL_SSLVERSION_MAX_TLSv1_2);
    easy.SetOpt(CURLoption.SSL_OPTIONS, (int)CURLSSLoption.CURLSSLOPT_NATIVE_CA);

    easy.SetOpt(CURLoption.USERNAME, FTP_USERNAME, Encoding.UTF8);
    easy.SetOpt(CURLoption.PASSWORD, FTP_PASSWORD, Encoding.UTF8);

    easy.SetOpt(CURLoption.PROXYTYPE, CurlProxyType.Socks5);
    easy.SetOpt(CURLoption.PROXY, PROXY_HOST, Encoding.UTF8);
    easy.SetOpt(CURLoption.PROXYPORT, PROXY_PORT);
    easy.SetOpt(CURLoption.PROXYUSERPWD, $"{PROXY_USERNAME}:{PROXY_PASSWORD}", Encoding.UTF8);
}

curl_global_trace("all");

// WORKS WITH TWO EASY HANDLES

DebugConsole.DebugLines.Add("***** Running MLSD on first handle *****");

using (var easy = new CurlEasy())
{
    Configure(easy);
    easy.SetOpt(CURLoption.CUSTOMREQUEST, "MLSD", Encoding.ASCII);
    easy.WriteFunction = Receive;
    easy.SetOpt(CURLoption.NOPROGRESS, 0);

    try
    {
        easy.Perform();
    }
    catch (CurlException e) when (e.CURLcode == CURLcode.FTP_COULDNT_RETR_FILE)
    {
        // Expected
    }
}

DebugConsole.DebugLines.Add("***** Running LIST on second handle *****");

using (var easy = new CurlEasy())
{
    Configure(easy);
    easy.SetOpt(CURLoption.CUSTOMREQUEST, "LIST", Encoding.ASCII);
    easy.WriteFunction = Receive;
    easy.SetOpt(CURLoption.NOPROGRESS, 0);

    easy.Perform(); // Does not throw, i.e. SUCCESS
}

// DOES NOT WORK WITH ONE REUSED EASY HANDLE

DebugConsole.DebugLines.Add("***** Running MLSD on handle *****");

using (var easy = new CurlEasy())
{
    Configure(easy);
    easy.SetOpt(CURLoption.CUSTOMREQUEST, "MLSD", Encoding.ASCII);
    easy.WriteFunction = Receive;
    easy.SetOpt(CURLoption.NOPROGRESS, 0);

    try
    {
        easy.Perform();
    }
    catch (CurlException e) when (e.CURLcode == CURLcode.FTP_COULDNT_RETR_FILE)
    {
        // Expected
    }

    DebugConsole.DebugLines.Add("***** Running LIST on reused handle *****");

    // Reset and reuse
    easy.Reset();
    Configure(easy);
    easy.SetOpt(CURLoption.CUSTOMREQUEST, "LIST", Encoding.ASCII);
    easy.WriteFunction = Receive;
    easy.SetOpt(CURLoption.NOPROGRESS, 0);

    try
    {
        easy.Perform();
    }
    catch (CurlException ex) when (ex.CURLcode == CURLcode.FTP_WEIRD_PASV_REPLY)
    {
        Console.WriteLine("!!! TEST FAILED !!!");
        DebugConsole.DebugLines.Add("***** Got unexpected FTP_WEIRD_PASV_REPLY *****");

        foreach (var line in DebugConsole.DebugLines)
        {
            Console.WriteLine(line);
        }

        throw;
    }
}

static class DebugConsole
{
    public static List<string> DebugLines = [];

    public static unsafe IntPtr DebugFunction(
        IntPtr handle,
        curl_infotype type,
        IntPtr data,
        UIntPtr size,
        IntPtr clientp
    )
    {
        var span = new Span<byte>(data.ToPointer(), (int)size);
        DebugLines.Add(
            DateTime.Now.ToString("HH:mm:ss.fff") + " " + Encoding.ASCII.GetString(span)
        );
        //Debug.WriteLine(
        //    DateTime.Now.ToString("HH:mm:ss.fff") + " " + Encoding.ASCII.GetString(span),
        //    type.ToString()
        //);
        return 0;
    }
}

```

Well, I see

```
13.53.12.558 [1-0] [SSL-1] SSL_connect() -> err=0, detail=5
13.53.12.558 TLS connect error: error:00000000:lib(0):func(0):reason(0)
13.53.12.558 LibreSSL SSL_connect: SSL_ERROR_SYSCALL in connection to ftpserver.com:21
13.53.12.558 [1-0] [SSL-1] cf_connect() -> 35, done=0
```
an SSL error on the DATA connection of the second transfer. If you say that the error "disappears" when debug logging takes too long, could it be that MS FTP has some limitation on doing another PASV SSL handshake or some Windows Anti-Virus/Firewall/Security thing interferes here?

If you do a `sleep(2000)` after the `curl_easy_reset()` does the problem also go away?
Inserting a 5 second delay either before or after the call to reset does not fix the issue.

Thanks for checking. Now I see that after the `EPSV` and before the DATA connection is fully handshaked, curl sends a `LIST` command on the control connection. 

Update: ah, that is an intended custom request. kk.

Observation:
transfer 0: 
 * sends `EPSV`, gets `229`
 * sends `TYPE A`, gets `200`
 * sends `MLSD`, gets `500`
 * ends

transfer 1:
 * sends `EPSV`, gets `229`
 * sends `LIST`, SSL on DATA fails
 * sends `PASV`, gets List response `150`
 * is confused

Another observation: I do not see that transfer 0 closes the DATA connection after the 500. That seems wrong. Maybe that is why the server does not want to open a second DATA connection in transfer 1?

@rmja if you change the first command from `MLSD` to something the server understands, will the second transfer work?

Yes, sending a valid quote before the reset makes the second transfer work. I tried sending:
* LIST (returning OK) -> reset -> LIST (returning OK as expected)
* MLSD (returning FTP_COULDNT_RETR_FILE as expected) -> reset -> LIST (now returning FTP_WEIRD_PASV_REPLY which is incorrect)

issue.title: ftp: fix teardown of DATA connection in done

repository.name: curl
repository.description: A command line tool and library for transferring data with URL syntax, supporting DICT, FILE, FTP, FTPS, GOPHER, GOPHERS, HTTP, HTTPS, IMAP, IMAPS, LDAP, LDAPS, MQTT, POP3, POP3S, RTMP, RTMPS, RTSP, SCP, SFTP, SMB, SMBS, SMTP, SMTPS, TELNET, TFTP, WS and WSS. libcurl offers a myriad of powerful features

issue.body:
When ftp_done() is called to terminate the transfer, it needs to tear down any open SECONDARY filter chain. The condition on when to do that was relying on there to be a valid socket. This is not sufficient as the socket is only set *after* happy eyeballing has decided on one.

Instead of checking for a valid conn->sock, check if any connection filter is installed.

refs #17482

body:
I made #17491 as a fix for the dangling connection from the first transfer that then makes the second fail.

If you could verify that against your server, that'd be very helpful as we have no access to an MS FTP one. Thanks!
Awesome. I can check it from the daily build when it gets merged.
Hi both of you. Just wanted to confirm that the latest daily windows build has this issue actually resolved. Thank you!
